posts.cooked:
What voltage does your team charge batteries to?

We have two of these chargers ( https://www.andymark.com/products/battery-charger-3-bank-6-amp-dual-pro-rs3-with-sb-50a-connectors ) and I haven’t seen them get a battery above ~13.5v (and usually they do ~12.7v) but at competitions when we borrow batteries from other teams I’ve seen them charged as high as 14.5v and have many fewer brownout issues with these overcharged batteries. Are we doing something wrong here?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: here to learn about building robots

posts.custom_user_title: here to learn about building robots

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Confusingly fully charged voltage on a 12v lead acid cell is somewhere north of 13v. This is true on cars too (same battery chemistry, 6 2v cells in series) although this chemistry has a higher tendency to vent as the voltage rises. I think most voltaic cells do this higher voltage thing, I’m not sure if electrolytic cells follow the same pattern as they recharge and how that works with the electrical to chemical energy… (something something forgot), as the states are slightly different.

Lithium Ion cells are a different ball game all together.

(source: old probably questionable chemistry knowledge)

To answer your question though: as high as my charger will let me, so probally around 13.8-14.5V

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Skyehawk:

Lithium Ion cells are a different ball game all together.

LiFePO4 cells routinely charge high. For a 24V battery, you’ll get about +5 volts. For a 12V, +2.5 or so. You don’t wanna know how high 48V goes…

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Would 58V be a good guess? XD

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
57.6, close enough. Charges at 59 or 60.

Anyways, back on topic:

A fully-charged 12V SLA is going to be somewhere around 13V. If there’s a charger doing closer to 14.5, I’d take a good look at the charger–IIRC, 12V LiFePO4 chargers hit 14.4V nominal, and using a LiFePO4 charger on a SLA battery is, er, an “interesting” choice (and may not actually work). Or it’s just a particularly good charger, and it’s been working on the batteries all day instead of for a couple of hours.

(Also… there ARE LiFePO4 batteries in an FRC-legal form factor. Weight and discharge rate are problematic, though. If you borrow a battery, double-check the chemistry…)

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
Winston89:

I’ve seen them charged as high as 14.5v

Those high initial post-charge voltages are just surface charge.  It doesn’t provide any meaningful capacity difference - as soon as you start drawing current it dissipates.  That’s why your Battery Beak may tell you you’re at “130%” charge - sadly, you can’t actually stuff an extra 30% into the battery, much as we’d all like to do that!

Here is a graph from a test on one of last year’s batteries with our BD250 discharger that illustrates the phenomenon - note that the initial voltage immediately drops as soon as you put a load on the battery. 2022-008_06Nov22_11Vcutoff 939×364 35.4 KB

2022-008_06Nov22_11Vcutoff 939×364 35.4 KB

2022-008_06Nov22_11Vcutoff 939×364 35.4 KB

In fact I had to go looking for this screenshot because the ‘normal’ 30-second-interval data logs that we keep don’t even capture the initial value since by 30s in, it’s long gone.

Winston89:

have many fewer brownout issues with these overcharged batteries. Are we doing something wrong here?

I would not necessarily assume the difference is due to the initial charge voltage, but would consider other differences in battery treatment and usage.  It may be that the borrowed batteries are newer, or have been better treated ( FRC batteries in general live hard lives).  It is also worth carefully inspecting your battery harness connections for anything loose or corroded - at 200A, even a small assembly issue can cause real problems.

link_counts.title: Why are there no COTS differential swerves?

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
EricH:

Also… there ARE LiFePO4 batteries in an FRC -legal form factor.

Legal form-factor, maybe, but not legal for competition:

R601 *Battery limit – everyone has the same power. The only legal source of electrical energy for the ROBOT during the competition, the ROBOT battery, must be 1 and only 1 non-spillable sealed lead acid (SLA) battery with the following specifications:

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Doesn’t mean someone won’t try to sneak one in. Have your inspectors asked to check all of your batteries?

Agreed that it’s not legal, and if someone were to try it it would fail miserably on reasons both legal and technical.

bbonner:

It may be that the borrowed batteries are newer, or have been better treated

is there a battery maintenance best practices thread anywhere on here? I’ve searched for one but haven’t found anything useful.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: here to learn about building robots

posts.custom_user_title: here to learn about building robots

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
Winston89:

is there a battery maintenance best practices thread anywhere on here?

There have been some excellent and in-depth discussions of various battery topics along the way, but I don’t know of a specific best-practices thread.  That said, as with many things, I think common sense covers most of the cases.  Here’s the main ones I would list.  I will skip topics relating to managing fleets of FRC batteries across years, and limit myself to how to take care of the ones you own.

Use a good quality charger. You want a charger that will carefully charge, then maintain the battery in a safe and comfortable state if left connected.

Don’t abuse the battery. Don’t lift by the harness, avoid impacts/drops, retire if damaged/leaking.

Label every battery including its year (we number as year-battery, e.g. 2022-001, 2022-002, etc.).  When a battery reaches the point where it shouldn’t be used in competition, flag it prominently so it doesn’t accidentally get put in a robot.

Rotate batteries to spread the wear and tear across all of them.  Labeling helps here.

Store your batteries charged. If at all possible, top them up regularly during periods they’re not heavily used.  Definitely don’t let them sit dead when you come back from a competition.

Break in new batteries. They will take at least 5 and possibly as many as 20 cycles to fully break-in (MK Battery says their AGM batteries require 15-20 cycles).   Ideally use a discharger at a moderate rate (7.5A is commonly recommended); full-on robot driving is very hard on a battery and not a great way to break them in, though we have done it.  If you must break in on a robot, try to take it easy.

Don’t over-discharge your batteries. If you’re browning out during drive practice or other work at your shop, stop and change the battery right away, don’t try to push it.  Never leave a robot on when you leave, as it will drain the battery to a very low level.  If using a discharger for break-in or testing, don’t take the battery below 10.8V (==1.8V/cell for our 6-cell batteries).

Avoid temperature extremes. Don’t store or charge in very cold or hot environments.

Keep cable harnesses tight and check them periodically.

posts.name: Newton Crosby Jr
posts.cooked:
A full battery will have somewhere north of 13 volts. However, to keep your batteries healthy and performing well (yes, batteries can be starved and overfed), you should try to charge them up to full (a CTRE BatteryBeak will read 130%, but that’s really just full) charge and use them to about 50% before plugging them back in. That sort of ‘life cycle’ is the best way to keep your batteries from decaying to fast. There’s a whole ton of chemistry and stuff behind the acids and whatever, but the td;dr for battery management is charge to full, use to 50%, charge to full, and so on. Don’t overcharge them or keep them dead, because the acids will start to corrode the other components in the battery.

PS: I go more into depth in this post: Very fast battery drain pls help - #15 by NewtonCrosbyJr

posts.name: Ender Wiggin
posts.cooked:
While higher float chargers will not add total capacity to the battery, they will improve the battery’s performance, especially within the time frame that they are used for FRC robots. Higher float charges do have the trade-off of shortening the total life span of the battery.

Here are three excellent threads on Lead-acid batteries:

How long do FRC Batteries last? Electrical

SLA Battery Wear: Literature Review Technical Discussion

Robot Battery Maximum Voltage Electrical

link_counts.title: How long do FRC Batteries last?

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: Most chargers manage the charging current, as opposed to the voltage.  So charging until the current drops below a certain amount may be a better way to go here.  In particular, many chargers have either a little status light or even a current meter you can check.
